frontmatter.title: Routines
frontmatter.description: There is balance between having and not having a routine. Having a routine can help you make progress. Not having a routine allows you to explore and find new sources of inspiration.

frontmatter.description: After school, effort and results don't necessarily correlate. For many things, results are binary. Either you succeed or you don't.

frontmatter.title: Advice for creating on the internet
frontmatter.description: Creating anything on the internet has extremely high leverage. The internet turns a linear amount of work into an exponential amount of value.

frontmatter.description: What you desire is imitated from observing what others desire or have.

frontmatter.title: The Sovereign Individual: Megapolitics
frontmatter.description: Megapolitics attempts to extract major structural patterns that repeat throughout history. The factors leading to megapolitical change include topography, climate, microbes and technology.

frontmatter.title: Balance inputs and outputs
frontmatter.description: Knowledge without application is useless. However, in a complex world abundant in information, it is easy to get overwhelmed into inaction.

frontmatter.title: What won't change?
frontmatter.description: 'What's not going to change in the next 10 years?' And I submit to you that that second question is actually the more important of the two -- because you can build a business strategy around the things that are stable in time.

frontmatter.description: This is the blog of Matthew Siu. A place to share my thoughts about my ever changing set of interests. One day, someone will feed this into an AI and make a digital copy of me. To be continued..

frontmatter.title: Humane Typography in the Digital Age
frontmatter.description: An Essay on Typography by Eric Gill takes the reader back to the year 1930. The year when a conflict between two worlds came to its term. The machines of the industrial world finally took over the handicrafts.

frontmatter.title: Johannes Gutenberg: The Birth of Movable Type
frontmatter.description: German inventor Johannes Gutenberg developed a method of movable type and used it to create one of the western world’s first major printed books, the “Forty–Two–Line” Bible.
